skill.name: medchem
skill.description: Medicinal chemistry filters. Apply drug-likeness rules (Lipinski, Veber), PAINS filters, structural alerts, complexity metrics, for compound prioritization and library filtering.
skill.summary: Medicinal chemistry filters. Apply drug-likeness rules (Lipinski, Veber), PAINS filters, structural ...
skill.author: K-Dense Inc.

security_audit.summary: Legitimate medicinal chemistry filtering tool. All operations are local file I/O using standard scientific Python libraries. No network calls, credential access, or malicious patterns detected.

content.user_title: Apply medicinal chemistry filters to compound libraries
content.value_statement: You need to prioritize drug-like compounds and remove problematic structures from your library. This skill applies established drug-likeness rules, structural alerts, and complexity metrics to deliver consistent, standardized filtering results.
actual_capabilities: Apply drug-likeness rules including Lipinski Rule of Five, Veber, Oprea, CNS, and leadlike
Run structural alert detection with PAINS, Common Alerts, NIBR, and Lilly demerits filters
Calculate molecular complexity scores using Bertz, Whitlock, and Barone methods
Apply property constraints for MW, LogP, TPSA, H-bond donors, and rotatable bonds
Detect chemical groups such as hinge binders, Michael acceptors, and reactive groups
Process compound libraries in parallel for high-throughput filtering
limitations: Requires local installation of medchem, datamol, pandas, and RDKit packages
Input restricted to CSV, TSV, SDF, or TXT files containing SMILES data
Filters provide guidelines only and do not guarantee biological success or drug efficacy
No built-in machine learning or predictive modeling for ADME properties

use_cases.title: Triage screening library
use_cases.description: Apply Rule of Five and PAINS filters to identify drug-like candidates from large compound collections.

use_cases.title: Lead optimization screening
use_cases.description: Combine leadlike rules, Lilly demerits, and complexity thresholds to select quality leads for optimization.

use_cases.title: Batch quality control
use_cases.description: Process compound libraries through multiple filters and generate detailed summary reports for downstream analysis.

prompt_templates.title: Basic library filter
prompt_templates.prompt: Filter my compound library using Rule of Five and Veber rules. Report how many molecules pass and save results to output.csv.

prompt_templates.title: Detect problematic structures
prompt_templates.prompt: Run PAINS and common alerts filters on my SMILES list. Tell me the pass rate and which molecules failed.

prompt_templates.title: Stricter lead criteria
prompt_templates.prompt: Filter molecules with leadlike strict rules, Lilly demerits max 100, and complexity max 400. Output only passing compounds.

prompt_templates.title: Custom property bounds
prompt_templates.prompt: Filter molecules with MW between 200 and 500, LogP from -2 to 5, TPSA max 140, H-bond donors max 5. Show violation details.

output_examples.input: Filter my CSV library using Rule of Five, Rule of CNS, and common alerts. Give me a summary.

best_practices: Start with broad filters like Rule of Five before applying strict lead optimization criteria
Use parallel processing (n_jobs=-1) for large compound libraries to improve speed
Document all filter settings and save summary reports for reproducibility and audit trails
anti_patterns: Treating filter pass results as definitive go or no-go decisions for clinical candidates
Skipping validation of invalid or malformed SMILES entries in input files
Mixing different input file formats in a single filtering run without proper preprocessing

faq.question: What platforms and environments support this skill?
faq.answer: It works in any Python 3 environment with medchem, datamol, pandas, and RDKit installed including local machines and cloud notebooks.

faq.question: Are there limits on the number of molecules I can process?
faq.answer: No hard limits exist but processing speed and memory usage depend on your local hardware and the number of parallel jobs configured.

faq.question: Can I integrate this into automated pipelines?
faq.answer: Yes, the script runs from command line and can be called from shell scripts, workflow managers, or other Python code using subprocess or library imports.

faq.question: Does my data leave my local environment?
faq.answer: No, all file operations are local. The skill reads your input files and writes output files only on your machine.

faq.question: Why did my run fail with missing column error?
faq.answer: Verify your CSV has a 'smiles' column or use --smiles-column to specify the correct column name. Check file encoding and format.

faq.question: How is this different from manual cheminformatics tools?
faq.answer: This applies standardized, reproducible rules consistently across all molecules without human variation and generates automated reports.
